dt: {bc}free from error especially as the result of care
{bc}conforming exactly to truth or to a standard {bc}{sx|exact||}
{bc}going to, reaching, or hitting the intended target {bc}not missing the target

dt.t: The next play, Johnson fielded a sharp grounder and made an {wi}accurate{/wi} throw to first.

pt: {sc}correct{/sc} {sc}accurate{/sc} {sc}exact{/sc} {sc}precise{/sc} {sc}nice{/sc} {sc}right{/sc} mean conforming to fact, standard, or truth. {sc}correct{/sc} usually implies freedom from fault or error.
{sc}accurate{/sc} implies fidelity to fact or truth attained by exercise of care.
{sc}exact{/sc} stresses a very strict agreement with fact, standard, or truth.
{sc}precise{/sc} adds to {sc}exact{/sc} an emphasis on sharpness of definition or delimitation.
{sc}nice{/sc} stresses great precision and delicacy of adjustment or discrimination.
{sc}right{/sc} is close to {sc}correct{/sc} but has a stronger positive emphasis on conformity to fact or truth rather than mere absence of error or fault.

et: borrowed from Latin {it}accūrātus{/it} {ldquo}prepared with care, studied, meticulous,{rdquo} from past participle of {it}accūrāre{/it} {ldquo}to give attention to, do carefully,{rdquo} from {it}ad-{/it} {et_link|ad-|ad-} + {it}cūrāre{/it} {ldquo}to watch over, care for{rdquo} {ma}{mat|cure:2|}{/ma}
shortdef: free from error especially as the result of care
conforming exactly to truth or to a standard : exact
able to give an accurate result
